Description: A hollow terracotta figure of a grotesque cult-attendant carrying, in a procession, on his left shoulder, a statue of Harpokrates. The theophoros (god-bearer), who is somewhat corpulent, wears a himation rolled above his belly, the drapery covering his legs; his upper body is naked. He has a ribbon holding two lotus buds on top of his bald head. A pottery vessel is held in his right hand, but only its neck survives. Harpokrates is naked and has his finger to his mouth. His hair is shaved except for a side-lock and he wears a hemhem crown. There is very summary treatment at the rear; part of a circular vent remains. The bearer has lost his legs below the knees and part of the back is missing. Two-piece mould. Brown Nile silt, with some mica.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased. Gustav Moustaki Collection. Probably Ptolemaic, third to second century BC. Comparanda: Close, perhaps from same mould-series: Dunand 1990: no. 512, from Antinoopolis, dated second to third century AD: this example shows that the pot is a 'lagynos', and that the 'theophoros' had an enormous phallus that curved over the plinth. Near: Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. 1872.1035, acquired by the vendor in the Fayum; Perdrizet 1921: 114. Bibliog: Vassilika 1994: 180, no. 31.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3151)
Condition: Fair. Back broken with some loss.
